text.p: Molten salts have been widely used as energy storage materials in medium-and high-temperature thermal energy storage. However, pure salt commonly suffers from low thermal conductivity and many conventional methods of heat transfer enhancement do not apply due to the serious corrosion and the extremely high temperature. In the current study, the open-cell SiC ceramic foam was integrated with solar salt (60wt% NaNO 3 + 40wt% KNO 3 ) to enhance the heat transfer of salt and avoid severe corrosion issues. A visualised experiment was for the first time conducted to investigate the melting phase change heat transfer in the ceramic foam/molten salt composite phase change material (CPCM). A representative elementary volume (REV)-scale simulation was simultaneously performed and the computational results were compared with experimental data. It is found that the conduction-friendly ceramic skeleton remarkably enhances the heat transfer in molten salt, especially in the region far away from the heat source. The spatial temperature difference across the composite is decreased in both horizontal and vertical directions and the local superheating is mitigated. The enhancement of heat conduction is greater than the suppression of natural convection; as a result, the melting rate of the CPCM is increased by 41.3%. This study provides crucial benchmark data of phase change heat transfer for medium-temperature thermal energy storage and paves the way for system design and optimization.Molten salts have been widely used as energy storage materials in medium-and high-temperature thermal energy storage. Using renewable energy is one of the most effective methods to cope with the worldwide energy crisis and environmental pollution [1][2][3] . Some energy resources, such as solar energy, have the drawbacks of intermittence and instability, which hampers their efficiency seriously [4] . To address this problem, latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) was proposed [5][6][7] . This technology stores thermal energy in phase change materials (PCMs) and releases it when the energy is needed [ 8 , 9 ]. According to the melting point of PCMs, thermal energy storage is classified as lowtemperature (melting point < 100 °C), medium-temperature (melting point 10 0-30 0 °C) and high-temperature (melting point > 300 °C) ones [10] . Molten salts have been widely used as medium-and high-temperature energy storage materials due to their appropriate melting point, large energy storage density, low cost, excellent thermal stability, etc. [11][12][13][14] . In integrated organic Rankine cycle (ORC) systems where solar heat is converted into power, heat transfer fluid (HTF) absorbs heat in the solar collector and flows to the molten salt tank where heat is stored. The storage tank supplies stable heat to the ORC sub-system, maintaining ORC operating under design conditions and overcoming the instability of solar radiation. However, almost all pure PCMs except metals suffer from low thermal conductivity [13] . For molten salt, the low thermal conductivity means a slow charging/discharging rate, which impairs the efficiency of solar power plants and decreases the output power. Many methods have been proposed to enhance the heat transfer of pure PCMs. For low-temperature PCMs such as paraf- fin, the metal foam and fins have been extensively studied and proved to be good thermal promoters [4] . But for molten salt, these heat transfer enhancement technologies may not apply because the metal foam and fin can be corroded by molten salt [16] , and they can soften in the extremely high-temperature environment. Ceramics have inherently high thermal conductivity and excellent corrosion-resistant performance [17][18][19] . Some researchers have studied using ceramics to enhance the heat transfer of molten salts. Liu et al. [20] prepared a ceramic-based composite phase change material (CPCM) where mullite-corundum act as the porous skeleton and Na 2 SO 4 as PCM. Jiang et al. [21] designed three Na 2 SO 4 -NaCl/ceramic CPCMs. They found that the addition of α-alumina and mullite mitigated the supercooling of the eutectic Na 2 SO 4 -NaCl. Furthermore, these composites had good thermal stability under 20 thermal cycles. Wang et al. [22] fabricated a ternary salt/Si 3 N 4 CPCM using the pressure impregnation method. Their results indicated that the thermal conductivity of the composite was more than six times higher than that of pure ternary salt. Xu et al. [23] utilised the diatomite to load NaNO 3 . However, the composite was found to have a low thermal conductivity of ∼0.5 W/m K. Authors added 10 wt% graphite and the thermal conductivity was improved by six-folds. Jiang et al. [24] developed a modified diatomite-based CPCM. CaCO 3 powders were added into diatomite and the mixture was sintered at 1150 °C to obtain the porous skeleton. The prepared CPCM exhibited excellent cycling stability during 500 thermal cycles. It is noted that the above mentioned ceramic-based composites are shape-stabilised PCMs; in other words, the pore size is very small, in the magnitude of micron and nanometre, so the fluid is restricted by capillary force and surface tension and the leakage is prevented. In terms of open-cell ceramic skeleton, Liu et al. [25] used the foaming method to prepare a large-pore ceramic-based CPCM where the maximum pore size was in the magnitude of a millimetre. The open-cell configuration enables natural convection and benefits the heat transfer enhancement. The thermal conductivity of prepared CPCM is reported to be 31.8-52.6 W/m K. Luo et al. [26] fabricated nanoparticle-molten salt-ceramic CPCM with synergetic enhanced specific heat capacity, thermal conductivity and optical absorption. The specific heat capacity and thermal conductivity of CPCM are 4.9% and 159% higher than that of pure salt respectively. Phase change heat transfer is of fundamental importance for determining thermal-fluidic behaviours of PCMs and optimising the performance of thermal energy storage (TES) systems [4] . Some researchers have studied the phase change heat transfer characteristics of porous CPCMs. Li et al. [27] experimentally and numerically studied the melting phase change heat transfer of paraffin saturated in open-cell metal foams. The effect of foam morphology including porosity and pore size on the wall temperature and temperature uniformity was investigated. Zheng et al. [28] studied the effect of heating position on the phase change heat transfer of paraffin/copper foam CPCM. They found that PCM heated at the top melted slowest and the temperature difference was the largest. Yao et al. [29] carried out a pore-scale study on the melting heat transfer of paraffin/copper foam. The solid-liquid interface and temperature field were captured to visualise the detailed melting phenomenon. Yang et al. [30] numerically investigated the melting phase change of open-cell foam embedded paraffin. Their results indicate that natural convection exerts a significant influence on the melting front shape, temperature distribution and melting rate.Phase change heat transfer is of fundamental importance for determining thermal-fluidic behaviours of PCMs and optimising the performance of thermal energy storage (TES) systems [4] . Although there are extensive studies on the phase change heat transfer of PCMs, studies on heat transfer characteristics of ceramic foam-enhanced molten salt are rarely reported, especially the vi- sualised ones [4] . In the current study, the open-cell SiC ceramic foam was integrated with solar salt (60 wt% NaNO 3 + 40 wt% KNO 3 ) to enhance the heat transfer of salt. A visualised experiment was conducted to investigate the phase change heat transfer characteristics of the ceramic foam/molten salt CPCM, including solid-liquid interface, temperature field and melting rate. The heat transfer experiment of pure solar salt was also conducted to make a comparison. In addition, a representative elementary volume (REV)-scale simulation was performed to further understand the thermal-fluidic transport process. Molten salts are suitable latent heat storage media in solar thermal power generation applications [ 15 , 31-33 ], where the ceramic foam/molten salt CPCM with enhanced heat transfer performance can be a promising candidate. The porous SiC ceramic foam was prepared using the dipping method. The schematic of the preparation process is shown in Fig. 1 . First, the polyurethane (PU) foam (Yueyang Sponge Co., Ltd) with the pore size of 10 PPI was submerged in NaOH solution for 12 h to activate the surface [34] . Then, it was dipped in the SiC ceramic slurry. The slurry consists of SiC powder (particle size:10-13 μm, Xianfeng Material Co., Ltd), kaolin, alumina, yttrium oxide (Yousuo Chemical Co., Ltd), carboxymethylcellulose sodium (CMC), sodium polyacrylate, silica sol, polyvinyl alcohol (Yousuo Chemical Co., Ltd), N-octanol (Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd) and water. The mass ratio of SiC, kaolin, alumina and yttrium oxide is 86: 7: 4: 3. The mass fraction of these solid powders is 77.9%. CMC, sodium polyacrylate, N-octanol were used as the tackifier, dispersant and defoamer respectively while silica sol and polyvinyl alcohol were employed to improve the adhesion of the slurry to PU foams. A REV-scale simulation was performed to obtain some detailed heat transfer information and assist in understanding the melting phase change heat transfer [4] . The REV-scale simulation treats the porous CPCM as a uniformly mixed medium and does not require an accurate description of the porous skeleton. In other words, it ignores the complex geometric information of the medium. This method uses some statistical parameters, such as porosity, permeability and effective thermal conductivity, to characterize the porous structure. The disadvantage is that it cannot reveal the flow and heat transfer characteristics in pores. But due to the simple input and low computational cost, it is a powerful tool for simulating large-scale systems [36] . The two-temperature model considers the thermal nonequilibrium between PCM and the porous skeleton [4] . It was used in the current simulation to model the phase change heat transfer and flow process in ceramic foam/solar salt CPCM. Before establishing the model, the following assumptions were made: (1) the porous skeleton and PCM are homogenous and isotropic; (2) the flow of liquid PCM is laminar and incompressible; (3) the liquid PCM is subjected to the Boussinesq approximation and (4) the volume difference of PCM before/after melting is neglected.The two-temperature model considers the thermal nonequilibrium between PCM and the porous skeleton [4] . The numerical simulation was performed using ANSYS Fluent 18.0 package. The governing equations were discretized using the finite volume method. The SIMPLE scheme was employed to couple pressure and velocity. The second-order upwind method was implemented to discretise pressure, momentum and energy terms. The under-relaxation factors for pressure, density, body forces, momentum, liquid fraction update and energy were set as 0.3, 1, 1, 0.7, 0.9 and 1 respectively. The convergence criteria for conservation equations of continuity, momentum and energy were 10 -4 , 10 -4 and 10 -8 respectively.

Thus, it is expected that the simulated melting is faster than the experimental measurements. Nevertheless, the shape and the evolution trend of the simulated phase interface is consistent with experimental results. The simulated solid-liquid phase interface at the plane of x = 10 mm is presented in Fig. 6 . Due to the high thermal diffusivity of the quartz, the melting rate of the edge region is faster than that of the middle region. The velocity magnitude of the CPCM is obviously smaller than that of the pure PCM, where the maximum velocity of the liquid PCM in the former is about 9 × 10 -4 m/s while that in the latter can reach up to 2.2 × 10 -3 m/s. This is because, in the pure PCM, the liquid PCM flows freely while in the CPCM, the fluid flow is restricted by the inertial and viscous resistance induced by the porous skeleton [45] . The low velocity of the liquid PCM means that the natural convection is weakened. As seen in Fig. 5 , the bottom region of the liquid salt in CPCM is wider than that in pure PCM, which confirms natural convection is weaker in CPCM. Nevertheless, the seriously sloped interface of the CPCM suggests that natural convection still plays a non-negligible role in heat transfer. It may be attributed to the open cells and large pores of the ceramic foam. The addition of the ceramic foam obviously accelerates the melting. Moreover, it is seen from the simulated phase fields that the mushy region of CPCM is wider than that of pure PCM, indicating that the spatially synchronous phase change is boosted. The mushy region is the region where the temperature decreases from the liquidus temperature (246.0 °C) to the solidus temperature (222.9 °C). In the current study, the porous SiC ceramic foam was integrated with solar salt and the melting phase change heat transfer in the composite phase change material (CPCM) was studied. A visualised experiment was conducted to capture the solid-liquid phase interface, temperature field, etc. In addition, a representative elementary volume (REV)-scale simulation was performed to provide detailed heat transfer and flow information. A visualised experiment was conducted to capture the solid-liquid phase interface, temperature field, etc. In addition, a representative elementary volume (REV)-scale simulation was performed to provide detailed heat transfer and flow information. The following conclusions are drawn:

(1) Using ceramic foam is an effective method to enhance the heat transfer of molten salt. In the current experiment, the melting rate of molten salt/ceramic foam CPCM is increased by 41.3% compared to pure molten salt. (2) The temperature field of CPCM is more uniform.
